text: [music playing]

Welcome to
Conversations with Leaders.
My name is Scott Mullins,

Managing Director of Worldwide
Financial Services Business
and Market Development at AWS.
With me today is Su Shan Tan,

Managing Director and Group
Head of Institutional Banking at DBS.

Sue Shan, number one,
it's great to see you again.
And thank you for joining us today.
Thank you for having me.

Listen, you have walked
a very interesting path

to become one of Asia's
most respected
and influential business leaders.

And that, by the way,
includes serving

as a member
of parliament in Singapore.
Can you tell us a little bit about

DBS, number one, your current role,
and then your career?
How did you get to where you are?

So DBS was started 52 years ago
by the Singapore government,
essentially to develop Singapore.

So our origins was
the Development Bank of Singapore.

And that sort of purpose
and ethos of developing countries,

developing customers and creating
businesses, creating commerce,

and enabling success
and creating wealth

is a common purpose
on which we were built on.
As for me, well, I am Singaporean,

but I’ve spent a lot of my
working life overseas.
I started my working life in London.

I worked in Hong Kong, Tokyo,
and I came back to Singapore.

Like you, I started life
on the equity trading room.

I was an equity derivatives person
in London for many years.

So that was fun when
they still needed humans.

Well, that's something
I'm very proud of.
I know in my own career,

and I know you're proud of that
experience in yours as well.

Hey, I'd like to start
our conversation

by talking about something else
that you're proud of,
you've mentioned it.
It's the bank digital platform.

And when we talk about
digital innovation,

many people immediately talk
about digital banking.

Let's talk about the digital
banking platform at DBS,
that really is putting the customer

at the center
of the banking experience.

Tell us about the customer
experience.
How does that create value for DBS?
So let me just bring you back.

So DBS stood for the Development
Bank of Singapore,

as I said, given our roots
of developing the country.

And I often joke that it's now
become the digital bank of Singapore,
the D became digital.

But if we get our jobs right,
and we really do a good job,

we will disappear and will become
the disappearing bank of Singapore.

So DBS disappears
into our customers journey.

We disappear into our customers
everyday lives.

We just, you know,
go into their platforms,
their UX, and you can't see us.
It's like the Intel chip in your PC.
It's there.
It works.

It's seamless, it's intuitive,
but it disappears.

So that's kind of, you know,
the vision that we had.

And really, to get that vision
a reality, we had to do three things.

And the first was reset
the technology organization, right,

really go
from monolithic legacy systems
to microservices into the cloud.

The second was to really change
the culture of the bank.

Now, you know, we often say culture
eats strategy for breakfast,
and changing the culture of the bank,

how do you create a startup culture
in a company that has 28,000 people?

Right, so really,
really going into that.
And then last and very importantly,

how do you get into the customer's
every day journey?

How do you empathize
with the customer?

How do you disappear
into their journeys?

And so taking those three big themes
was how we started
to create our digital platform.

We set up on
the customer journey site,
the Human Centered Design laboratory,

which really put us
into the customers eyes,
mind, psychology, user experience.

We had our customers come in,
play with our UX,
play with our applications.

We looked if they could find stuff
on the menu bar,

we looked if they were upset
that they couldn't get stuff
they wanted straight away.

We figured out or asked them
what they wanted.

So the key was to get the customer
immersion right.

We often joke in the past that people
hated going to banks,

you know, it was worse
than going to see a dentist.
It was painful.

And how do you make that journey
less painful and more joyful?

And that's how we came up
with the concept of joyful banking,

which in the past, we thought
might be a bit of an oxymoron,

but really it was to bring the
customer experience to the forefront
and make it a happy one.

Well, that focus on customers
and that willingness to experiment,
it's paying off.

Last year the bank was recognized
for serving customers
in their time of need.

Obviously, we had a year like hardly
any others,

at least no others that
we've experienced in our lifetime,

based on the pandemic that we're
currently even still experiencing,

how did you balance
between serving your customers,

and then also taking care
of your own organization?

When COVID hit, it was always,
you know,

employees first, customers first,
and let's just do the right thing.

That overarching sense
of doing the right thing

and being purposeful was our
True North.
That we were the first bank

to have our first COVID
case in Singapore,

it was just get everyone home,
get everyone safe,
make sure everyone is safe.

And then let's look
after the customers, you know,

customers who previously only dealt
with paper and cheques and cash,

we had to teach them how to digitize
literally overnight, right?

So our people and our tech
business partners worked in overdrive

and what would have taken us,
I think, a year or year

and a half to really roll out,
we rolled out in six weeks.

So digital, you know,
so trade documents,
which have always been very paper

based became digitalized,
right, overnight.

When China had all that,
their issues around trade,

and the ports were disrupted,
as you know, this time last year,

we were one of the first
to bring OCR in,

digitize all the trades,
so that PPE could get in

and get out so that medical supplies
could get in and get out.

So it was just kind of quick pivot,
right?

You know, if you're agile,
and you're open to experimentation,

and you're guided by this culture
of doing the right thing,
you know, magic happens, right?

You just know what's
the right thing to do,

you can get everyone together
and create that spirit of can do
and do it with a purpose.

And I think that's what binds us
together through tough times,

like what we've gone
through last year.
Listen, a lot of what you said,

as you were talking,
I just kept thinking,

“Man, those are some problems that
probably needed some deep analysis,
but also some quick analysis.”

I know you guys think very much like
we do that financial institutions,
and specifically banks,

and retail facing
organizations are lucky

in that they do have
a lot of data at their disposal

in order to actually
solve problems for customers.
I'd love to just spend a few minutes

talking about how DBS is leveraging
data and analytics

to actually improve
the customer experience.
So, you're right.

I think banks have this treasure
trove of customer data

that I think a lot
of companies would kill for.

You know, we know a lot
about our customers.

And in the past,
I don't think we optimized this.

And I don't think if we put it
into as good to use
as we should and can do.

But the way to do it
is to really train our employees

to understand how to use this data,
how to recognize patterns.

And to then I want to give
you guys a shout out.

So last year during the COVID
lockdown,
we all downloaded the AWS DeepRacer.

And we learned how an AI
and machine learning helps,

to help us make better
sharper decisions
around the data that we have.

So if you can learn to drive
a virtual car,

run a race track faster
and quicker with data,

you sure as heck can learn
how to look after your customers
better with the right use of data.

The overarching ethos around
how we use our data is we're guided
by what we call the PURE Principle.
So P-U-R-E.
So what does PURE stands for?

So the P in PURE
stands for Purposeful.

So there must be a purpose behind
how we use the data,
is it relevant to the customer?

When we send them a contextual nudge,
was it relevant to them?
Did it make their lives better?
Was it a good offer for them? etc.

And then the U stands
for Unsurprising.

So they can't be surprised to get
that nudge or that, you know,

the offer from you
because you thought about it
and it wasn’t of a surprise.
And the R has to be Respectful.
So it shows the respect.
We're not using data we don't need.
And we don't use that.

If it's something that we need to do,
and we do it in a respectful way,

an unobtrusive way,
then the R is for respect.
And the E stands for Explainable.

You can explain why you use the data
the way you used it,
and it's not embarrassing to anyone.

So those are the PURE Principles
on which we work towards
in our data governance policy.

I think you have articulated
a very simple,

easy to understand data
governance policy
that also captures in the acronym

that you've given what should be
the intentions around

using very sensitive information
that's related to customers,

so congratulations on being able
to encapsulate that for your teams

in a very simple
but powerful message for them.

Su Shan, speaking of teams,
I'm so glad we've come to this point.

You have actually previously said
that changing the culture
was one of the toughest things to do,

and you actually mentioned that
when we started our conversation,
let's dive into it.
How did you and your teams do that?

Tell us about some of the hardest
things

and the biggest shifts
that you had to make an address?

You know, here in Singapore,
we have a concept called kiasu,

which is scared to lose,
scared to fail.

And so how do we kind of overcome
that deep cultural mindset
of not wanting to fail?

So we said, heck, why don't we
just celebrate failure?

Why don't we have
the failure rewards,

which really celebrated people
who dared to ask for money, right?

You know, you dared
to ask the boss for money.
You did that experiment.
It failed spectacularly.
But what did we learn from it?
And how can you get better next time?
Hey, great job.
Here's the award, right.

So celebrating those moments,
and having, you know, rituals.

So when you want to change
the culture of a firm,

that's this old and this big,
you really have to have rituals,

and they have to be simple rituals
that anyone can follow.

So the customer centricity one
was a ritual, hey, remember, we read,

right, respectful,
easy to do with dependable.

And then we also had meeting MOJOs,
M-O-J-O.
What's a meeting MOJO?

Well, the MO is
the meeting organizer.

So if you're the meeting organizer,
you're the MO, right.

So it's your job to make that meeting
a good one.
A happy meeting, if you will.

And the JO, the JO was
the joyful observer.

So that's someone who kind of,
you know, looks around at the meeting
and a joke and say, “Hey, hang on MO.

You know, you've been talking a lot
and I think we should open the floor

to people who haven't said
anything to say something.”

And then we have
the wreckoon moments,
a wreckoon is spelt W-R-E-C-K-O-O-N.
So someone who wrecked stuff.

So if you're going to wreck an idea,
it's okay, because you say,

“Hello, I'm going to be
a wreckoon here.”

And we go, “Okay, here we go,
wreck it.” And you wreck it, right.

And it's okay to wreck it because
you asked for a wreckoon moment.

So I think all these little rituals
will slowly

but surely change
the culture of the bank,
because it changes the way we work.
It changes the way we think.

It makes it okay to ask
the dumb questions.

It makes it okay to disagree
with a boss.

It makes it okay
to experiment and fail.

And I think when you have these kind
of areas of psychological safety
around what you do,

and how you do things as a team,
you do change the culture.

Yeah, I love that you guys make it
psychologically safe
for people to experiment,

and to really look at risk
in a different way.

And I think in financial services,
obviously,
it's a risk management business.

And I appreciate that you allow
people to feel comfortable

looking at risk in a different way
and approaching in a different way.

I think that's a hallmark for being
able to actually innovate.

Anything that comes to mind
for your...

on the experimental side
that didn't work?

So in 2014, my team
wanted to experiment with AI
for wealth management.

So creating an AI with a big company
and using the AI

to have a recommendation engine
for all our clients.
And it was really difficult.

And honestly,
I think at the end of day, we failed.
We didn't roll it out to customers.

We experimented a lot internally,
and we experimented with clients,

but you know, getting a machine
to answer customers questions on,
should I buy Tesla?

Or should I buy, you know,
Apple stock?
Or where's the dollar yen going?
Where’s Sterling going?
I mean, it was really difficult,

because the questions, you know,
had to be…
the answers had to be contextual,

you know, how long, when,
it said an overnight question,

it said is that timeframe a year,
a month,

and it had to fit in
with what the customer wanted.

And frankly, you didn't know
if you're going to be right or wrong.
So it wasn't deterministic.

And so I think the use case that
we had in that instance was wrong.
But we allow the experiment to happen

because I think the team learns
so much then about machine learning,

and the use of AI for seeing
natural language processing.
I learned a lot from that failure.
And the same team that still with us,

are now helping us with machine
learning and data analytics.
And I think that's great.

You've been very proactive
in helping women

succeed in the industry
for much of your career.

What advice would you give
to women aspiring

to take on
leadership positions in banking

or in the financial services
industry more broadly?

So I will tell them to not
just manage their inbox,
but to manage their outbox, right?
My CEO likes to talk about this.

And like it or not women,
particularly women in Asia too

still carry a heavy load
for the family.

And during COVID, a lot of women
had to do both,

look after the kids and look
after their aging parents,
especially in an Asian context.

But the good news is with COVID,
and everyone working from home,
both moms and dads,

I think it kind of equalized
a lot of that as well.

And it was okay for the dad
to work from home.

It was okay for dad to pick up kids
from school

or do the grocery shopping
or the cooking.

So I would encourage women to manage
their careers
and their trajectory more,

and to be not afraid to have those
conversations with your seniors

or your boss's boss and say,
“Hey, how am I doing?

What do I need to do
to get to the next level,
and to take some time out?

You know, can I use the flexible
work arrangements

I have but still keep
on the career ladder?

And how can you help me to keep
on the career ladder

whilst I still
have to do flexi work?” etc.

Well, thank you for sharing that
Su Shan.

And then would you mind also sharing
with us some of the current

initiatives that you're working on
that enable women?

And then maybe what you'd also
like to see in the future?

So about 19 years ago,
I started what's called

the Financial
Women's Association in Singapore.
It was a Singapore chapter.

And it was really to help women
in banking or financial services

with their professional careers,
especially as some of them

were leaving to have children
and needed a leg-in

to get back into the workplace,
or needed the network to help them,

or needed professional coaching,
or technical learnings.

And I'm very proud because that has
now grown to something really big

and it's become a great network
for women in finance to get ahead.
I'm no longer running it,

but it's bigger and better
than when I was, which is great.

And so we're helping a lot
of these young women

by providing their mentors,
by providing them opportunities,
making sure, I mean, I know at DBS

we always look at
the gender equation.

We actually have more women
than men in DBS today,

and we have a very high share
of women now at the top as well.

So I'm lucky, I mean, my CEO
and my chairman are great
advocates for women leadership.

So it's making it easier for them
to move up the career

whilst balancing families
and making it okay,

and saying, well, at times, you just
have to leave a meeting and go back,

pick up your son or daughter
and we'll say, well, it's okay.
If you need to do that, do it.

I really appreciate you sharing
that perspective with us

and the initiatives that
you're working on
to support women in the industry.

I want to thank you and the bank
for your partnership with us
on behalf of everyone here at AWS.

Personally, I also want to
thank you for your friendship.

It's always a wonderful opportunity
to sit down and visit with you.

Thank you for joining us
for Conversations with Leaders.

Thank you, Scott.
It's been a real pleasure.
[music playing]
